This game was nothing short of absolutely incredible. if you're reading this comment wondering "hmmm should I really buy this game" if you're into mechs even a little bit then yes yes YES.
This has to be the most immersive experience I've ever had playing a mech game. 
The story is amazing, Mech designs are cool as ever, and its really easy to follow what you're building, and what it can do. One of the best parts about that? they give you a training arena where you can switch things out accordingly in the middle of your training until you find exactly what you're looking for. 
This game gives the player a lot of freedom in playstyles. The game was also challenging in its own aspects, being a Fromsoft game and all. however, never so challenging that I didn't feel like I wasn't having fun EVER. 
i always felt i could figure out how to overcome any boss, obstacle, or mission. you can even build multiple mechs and save them and switch them out accordingly. that way you never have to sit there and build it again. 

 if Fromsoft ever drops a new AC game it will be in my cart within a matter of seconds. one of the best games I've ever played to date.

Pros:
- Gameplay. Oh, the gameplay. Engaging and satisfying once you nail the kind of playstyle you like. This isn't your usual souls-like esp if this is your first AC game like me. The game is fast, and if you can't adapt to the enemies speed either through sheer firepower or moving just as fast you'll have a rough time. 
- Replayability. Want to be a immovable fortress with enough firepower to cover your entire screen for 10 mins? Done. Want to be so fast the your brain can barely keep up but have the stopping power of a nuclear bomb? Done. Want to comfortably hover indefinitely as you rain napalm on your foes? Done. 
- Story is keeps you captivating and the VAs really immerse you into their world. If you want to fully experience the game you'll have to do multiple playthroughs and even in ng+ (esp ng++) i'm left feeling engaged and challenged.
- Writing and dialogue is meaningful. Each character has their values and motivation which you can't help but feel for them.
- The mechs and world is big and BEAUTIFUL. Some moments are so chilling and epic that you have to experience yourself.

Cons:
- The difficulty curve spikes in some boss fights [spoiler]*cough* balteus and IB-01: CEL 240 *cough*[/spoiler]. Which if people can't beat them they simply will stop playing and won't get to experience the whole game.
- If you don't have the specs to run this beast of a game all you'll get is a white screen.
- You may need a new controller. You'll be mashing your controller like your life depends on it, but don't mash too much or you'll be out of ammo. Unless of course you brought one of the many swords.

So, since the FromSoft games I'be been playing thus far haven't disappointed me, I thought to play another one, in this case Armored Core 6, which is a rather different (yet similar) beast from the FromSoft titles I have played thus far... And here's my thoughts and impressions of the game:

- The loot goblin in me is a bit disappointed of the lack of loot in this game, both in terms of 'loot you can pick up from downed enemies and 'loot you find/pick up'...

- When it comes to boss arenas, I really don't like the 'illusion of free movement' - that is to say, how our movements are restricted while the boss is totally free to move outside of the arena, which often gives them a bit of an advantage I'd rather not see them have AND sometimes ended up with me being cornered when this shouldn't have been the case...

- When it comes to OS tuning, I don't really like the fact that you have to reset EVERYTHING, even if you just want to change a small detail or two... And yes, I know; eventually you'll have enough points to just turn on everything in the OS, but nonetheless...

- A detail that makes me like it less than the other FromSoft games I've thus far is that if you quit during a mission... You've got to do it all over again. Meaning, if you've got trouble with a boss, there's no parking right outside or at least near enough the boss room. This wouldn't be so bad, if it was not for the fact that there's extra stuff to collect during many of the missions as well, so if you collect everything during a mission, but then end up struck at the boss and have to quit before you can finish it or the like... You've got to redo everything from the start (including defeating whatever minibosses andwhatnot there are between you and your objective), and this I find rather annoying.

- On a very minor note, I wish there was an achievement for replaying every single mission and getting a ranking for it - and yes, fair enough, there is such an achievement already, the 'Get an S rank in every mission'-achievement, but that's not quite the same thing; I daresay many of us replay the missions, but how many of us are crazy enough about it to do it so many times to get everything right for an S-rank? Not that many, I'd say, yet they do replay every mission, regardless...

- Visually speaking, the game offers some quite stunning sights, not just in terms of beauty, but in how enormous everything is - the 'Attack the weaponized mining ship' left me quite stunned, for example - and that was far from the only one! And when you realize just how your mech is in comparison to everything around you (normal vehicle, stairs, etc), it also makes it all the more stunning and impressive.

- Of note is how 'short' this game is in comparison to other FromSoft games I've played thus far. To compare, a single playthrough of DS1 took me over 100 hours, three playthroughs of AC6 took me less than 90 hours. This isn't too surprising, because you're doing missions rather than being given an open or semi-open world to explore and farm for items and/or souls/runes and suchlike. Even if one spends lots of time replaying missions for cash or finding the hidden stuff, or spend lots of time fiddling around with their AC, they'll probably only add about 10-20 hours to their playthrough this way at most, and those that spends little time on that may well end up completting the game in less time than I did (again, less than 90 hours - all three routes done). So from that perspective, it's a good game to go for if you don't want a game you might get stuck for hundreds of hours in.

- In-game equipment-wise, it's about as impressive as any other FromSoft game, though you'll be buying rather than finding most of the stuff. I'm sorry to say I had a harder time wrapping my head around what was, equipment-wise, good or not in this game than in the other FromSoft-games I've played thus far though... But that's hardly a problem everyone will be having.

- As far as replayability goes; things are decent in that department too. The game offers three different endings, some different choices when it comes to missions as well as some alternative versions of certain missions, though some of these won't appear until your second or third playthrough (if even that), so in short... The game gives you reasons to not just uninstall it after you're done with the first playthrough, and if you do play through the game more than once, there's bound to be differences from your first playthrough - unless you deliberately make all the same choices as the first time around, of course. 

When I bought and installed the game, what hoped for an experience similar - in both gameplay and story - to that of the Gundam-franchises, especially gameplay-wise... And I'd say I got what I wanted there, though story-wise, I'm not so certain. Regardless, it's a game I'd recommend to enthusiasts of the mecha-genre, soulslikes and FromSoft games - though it pays to be aware it'll be a different experience from FromSoft-games one has played thus far, unless one has played earlier games in the Armored Core-franchise. Probably to those who want a game that doesn't take overly long to play through as well...

All in all, AC6 is a game with fun and interesting gameplay, an interesting story, characters you won't exactly meet face-to-face in the game but still meet and find either interesting or annoying enough, challenging (sometimes annoyingly so) fights and plenty of stunning sights!

This is a robot/tech/mech/anime fantasy for fans of the genre, like me. The game has been out for a while, so I'm modding it at this point - to make it more enjoyable. The plot is a straightforward, by the numbers, story that provides ample excuses for you to blow up Big huge Boss mechs. It throws in ammo and energy management, which I think is out of place in a game that uses physics destroying mechs. Yes, MechWarrior has lots of that as well, but, whereas Mechwarrior seems more like a simulation with its own world rules that everyone follows - this game is an anime style fantasy where you fight enemies and bosses that don't have any of the constraints that you have to live with. Gameplay Mods help with that, and it turns the game into a more arcade like  experience - which is honestly what I was looking for.

I'll say again, simply a must-play.

The game is absolutely worth it, the campaign was worth playing it over 6 times in my experience. The variety of parts and play styles make it refreshing without feeling too overwhelming. The story and cinematic moments (plus secret events) is very engaging, not too mention the difficulty is just right. Can't say too much without spoiling the story, but it does have extra levels and routes after completing it the first time.

Unfortunately, that's where the good ends.

Fromsoft did great with the solo experience, however pretty much abandoned the game in every other department.
PvP is alright, netcode is poor though. And unless you play ranked mode, the game is pretty dead. Funnily enough, it's not even completely the fault of lack of updates. A big part of the blame is the community, it is full of big ego cry babies. Its either only using meta to have fun, or crying about how everything they lose to is meta. Have a kite build = meta, melee build that uses any high stagger gun = meta, shotguns = meta. missiles = meta. These aren't my words, just a lot of excuses made by players. I get it winning is fun, but take pride in a loss here and there. I used to really enjoy this game and for a good while it had a decent community, however, the toxicity killed any chance of momentum. If you like a toxic community, you found your home.

One word.....

PEAK.

That's how I would describe AC6, not only is it a banger game but it's also a fantastic introduction to the series for newcomers. Now I will admit, I would've liked to have more options in terms of parts like in previous games (Weapon Arms, Sniper Rifles, more options for reverse joints, Tetrapods, Tanks etc) This game definitly needs more in terms of content/options and I hope that gets rectified in a update or expansion/DLC. 

And I do feel the stagger/acs system could be tweaked as it can easily be abused with certain combinations.

But as it stands it's absalutely worth you're time and money, if you are a newcomber, a veteran or a Fromsoft fan that havn't played a Armored Core game before. 

Get this game, you wont regret it.

Your mech is highly customizable, and the depth and nuance of the stats make it easy to try but hard to master. The story is well presented, and the voice acting is well done for all the characters. I haven't tried the online, mostly because the anti cheat causes the game to lag which is really annoying, so I disabled the anti cheat.

Very satisfying gameplay, good story, mechfights...

10/10

Still, the environments are all pretty drab and the story is nothing to write home about so you really only play this for the combat. Nonetheless, I recommend it for the combat alone.

I was not sure if I would enjoy this one. It is quite different from FromSoftware's other titles, but it is strangely addictive and dodging rockets while shooting your own, showering enemies with minigun fire and slashing them with energy swords seems to work pretty well.
The game's mechanics are introduced slowly and it gives players space for experimentation. Take your time with it and it will reward you nicely. There is no excessive amount of cutscenes here. Gameplay is king, and this is a video game through and through, almost like something from the 2000s. Some text and speech before each level, then off you go to shoot the badies.
The action itself is pretty intense, and in typical FromSoftware tradition, expect a decent challenge here.

Good game, really satisfying combat. 

Not a ton of content, but the quality is really high.

I completed the new game ++ for the "real ending" in about 20 hours and completed all the achievements in 33. 

I would highly recommend AC6, the lore is fantastic, the music slaps, and the combat is addictive.

negative.review:
Man, I really want to like this one. The core idea is so good, but the game just isn't good. It starts great with some cool boss fights, but then the game runs out of ideas and each boss fight is less interesting than the previous one. It's a bit of a classic FromSoft problem, where the game is front-loaded and the latter parts of the game feel cobbled together to get the game out the door. 

The story is just awful. It's not even a fun kind of bad, it's just not good, worse, it's boring.

It's just a shame. I really want to like this game. I just don't have the energy to finish it though. It's not good enough and the competition if fierce.

I am rather underwhelmed coming from 4 Answer to this. It looks nicer due to modern graphics, the story is nice, but campaign could be a lot longer, theres a distinct lack of giant bosses to fights (most bosses are player sized) and a lack of 'companies' to take jobs for. I could do without the stun mechanic and a more generous variation of unique weapons and mech parts. Not worth full price

Honestly, I really liked this game, but after further play I realize I can't really recommend it. After going back and playing through other Armored Core games as well as other giant robot games both retro and modern, the fact that this is the game that is now the flag ship of the mecha genre is disappointing. Not because its worse than any of the other Armored Core games nor any other mecha game, but its disappointing that this is the best the genre has to offer. This is very easily one of the best if not the best Armored Core game out there. The game is extremely well polished, worked perfect on launch, and has no micro transactions or any major hickups, and the game can be extremely fun.
However, I just don't think this modernization of Armored Core works well. The Armored Cores of the past admittedly are not great. Many missions are just you destroying waves of clueless MT's that have no chance of beating you, until you come to a mission where you get absolutely destroyed by fighting 3 AC's at once. This game is far better than the Armored Cores of the past (don't take armored core fans word for it, actually go and play them and see for yourself if you don't believe me). But AC6 doesn't know what it wants to be. A big part of the Armored Cores of the past was that there was no healing. All the health you had was given at the start of the mission, this would turn certain missions into a game of learning how to navigate to the end while taking as little damage as possible for the boss. It also made your mechs feel more unique and specialized making you choose between just beefing up, or trying to be nimble and skilled enough to just avoid the damage all together. With the healing items and resupply mechanic in AC6, navigating through the map feels extremely trivial, almost like a waste of time. The combat is flashy and satisfying enough to where, on your first playthrough, you wont even notice how little they put up a fight. If somehow you manage to get through all your medkits fighting MT's, it doesn't even matter since you will autosave before you get to whatever boss you are going to fight. This mechanic in a weird way makes the game more frustrating, because if your build isn't cutting it for the boss, since you are mid mission you can't buy and sell parts to fit the job. So instead of just having the mission be the boss, you have to quit the mission, make your new mech, go fight your way back to the checkpoint, and then try your new build against the boss. This disincentivizes experimentation because the dark souls mentality (lets be honest that's why we ALL played this game) just tells you to keep fighting rather than back out, which while this can be satisfying, isn't what the Armored Core series has been about.
Speaking of the buy and sell system, while in the beginning this does lead to an interesting 4th dimension to mech building where you have to factor in the cost of parts, at a certain point in the game no matter what mech you want to build, if you just sell everything you can always make it (you get all your money back when selling parts). This just adds more friction to mech building requiring you to back out of the buy menu, go to the sell menu, sell all the parts you aren't currently using, then buy the ones you do. Even worse if it's a core in which you need to first buy the core you want, then swap, then sell. 
There are some really awesome missions in this game, but the majority of them just feel like the equivalent of orange waypoint AAA slop, just something to do because you have to do something. You don't really feel like the legendary Raven pilot, you feel like a fly swatter.
Like other AC games, you aren't necessarily getting attached to characters the same you would in a Baldurs Gate or a Tale Tale game or something. You just like them cause they are cool but nothing really beyond that. The ending quality varies WILDLY. The first ending I got absolutely blew me away and made me think about the game for weeks after I beat it, but after getting another ending, the ending most people probably would have gotten, I was extremely disappointed and felt completely unfulfilled after having going through the entire game again, which leads me to my last point.
This game isn't very replayable, but it very much tries to be. The mission replay system encourages you to replay missions to try and "S-Rank" them by beating them faster, taking less damage, ect, but doesn't present itself in a way that makes that satisfying. Maybe if there was an extra UI showing the time needed to S or the damage you can still take before going past the threshold while you are doing the mission it would feel better but you get nothing, once you are in the mission you are in the dark so it just feels unsatisfying. And most missions aren't interesting enough for you to even want to replay them, and you have to if you want to get all the endings, one of which requires you to get all other endings. 
But there still is a reason I have so much time in the game, and was my favorite game of 2023. The environments are beautiful and dreary. The sound design, particle effects, movement, and mech design are incredibly immersive and really give off this awesome feeling of dealing with truly extraordinary weapons and armor of the future. The aesthetic is raw and incredibly unique. The voice acting is, okay well the voice acting is really rough, but some characters like Handler Walter, Carla, Ayre, and Rusty, while not being fleshed out or honestly even really characters, are still presented in such a way that make them unforgettable (in certain endings). Where this game shines is what all AC games shine in, the customization, and this game turns it up to 11, letting you choose what type of weathering you want, how much weathering, differing finishes between matte and glossy, colors, your boosters, targeting systems, weapons, swap-able weapons. The cosmetic customization and the build variety is something I haven't been able to find in any other pilot game. This game showcases what is now exceedingly rare in the gaming industry, truly showing off things that can only be done by a AAA studio, and using that power to bring to reality something that fans of mecha or just gaming in general could only dream of a decade ago. It truly is an unforgettable game with spectacle I've never seen before. 
If you are truly passionate about the mecha genre, this is an absolute no brainer purchase, its the most important thing we have gotten in gaming, but Armored Core isn't yet at a point where I can truly recommend it to everyone, and I'm incredibly excited for when we get to that point.

Fromsoft once again fails to demonstrate improvement in areas where they struggle.

There is little reason that a studio like Fromsoft should struggle with displaying the correct button prompts for controllers in a game so clearly primarily designed for consoles.  The first bossfight is also poorly timed, with it clearly intending the player to use mechanics that are not explained until tutorials are accessed after the bossfight is successfully completed.  I suspect this second failure is due to poor planning on Fromsoft's part, with the introductory mission and boss being designed and implemented after the rest of the game was a finished piece - the studio has a history of such directorial blunders.

The game also seems to fall into the trap of attempting to display simplified stats for things like weapons while at the same time hiding useful information, leaving players relying on dataminers and extensive, laborious in-game testing to establish what *exactly* weapons do.

Additional features are poorly implemented.  The store system is unnecessary, providing no true limit on player builds past the very early game.  Engine load and weight already provide the necessary tools for balance.  Since you can buy and sell for the same price, in practice you simply buy, sell, buy, sell, buy, sell...it interrupts the flow of building, making the act of customizing your mecha a gigantic chore.

The story, as far as I have gotten, is poorly written and full of dull, unlikable characters with far too much dialogue for what they actually have to say.

Important missions are designed to be played halfway, failed, and restarted once the player has had a chance to tune their gear.  This is due to how the bossfights work, which are dependant on you having certain equipment to make them go by quickly enough to not drag on forever.  It's clear the devs are desperate for you to take a blade with you, but they only give you one blade for an extended period of time and it's kind of miserable to use.  It takes up a hand slot despite being  a wrist-mounted device.  You don't get any money for a failed mission, so it's just a way to waste player time.  

The "voice in your ear" characters are annoying to listen to, and only rarely have something useful to say.  Most of the commentary they give is cliche, and not in a funny way.  Just in a dull, unimaginative, hacky way.  Remember in Halo 2, how annoying it was to hear Cortana repeat the same voice line four or five times while trying to beat the game on higher difficulties?  It's that, but the character speaking never has any good lines to make up for it.  At least Cortana's lines in these situations tended to be more than "Don't let him bait you.  Focus."  

(Side Rant: He's not baiting ME you dumb fuck, he's baiting YOU.  I don't know who he is, I don't know who he's talking about, I don't give a single flying fuck about any of it.  Shut the hell up and let me do my job.  Like, at least do something useful and jam his comms so I don't have to hear his smug-ass dialogue)

Unfortunately, major mech games are rare and so it's still likely worth playing this game if you like mechs and can roll with the punches.  DO NOT pay full price for this title.  Fromsoft needs to be held to a standard appropriate for a professional, well-funded AAA studio.  If they put out a 30 dollar game that they take a loss on if they sell it for less than 50, that's not your problem.  That's their problem, and they can go bankrupt over it.


Edit:

I decided to see how far I could get,  I believe I got to the final boss of the first playthrough when I ran out of patience.  I just don't understand what people get out of this.  

If you decide to go ahead, understand that the game is *primarily* about what you have equipped.  Some weapons are simply much better than others.  Some weapons can excel in certain situations but are traps 90% of the time.  Some weapons do seem to just be bad.

I wish I could say I enjoyed my time, but the reality is that of the 40 hours I've spent with this game, I've enjoyed very little.

I could do without the stun mechanic and a more generous variation of unique weapons and mech parts. Not worth full price

Fromsoft once again fails to demonstrate improvement in areas where they struggle.

There is little reason that a studio like Fromsoft should struggle with displaying the correct button prompts for controllers in a game so clearly primarily designed for consoles.  The first bossfight is also poorly timed, with it clearly intending the player to use mechanics that are not explained until tutorials are accessed after the bossfight is successfully completed.  I suspect this second failure is due to poor planning on Fromsoft's part, with the introductory mission and boss being designed and implemented after the rest of the game was a finished piece - the studio has a history of such directorial blunders.

The game also seems to fall into the trap of attempting to display simplified stats for things like weapons while at the same time hiding useful information, leaving players relying on dataminers and extensive, laborious in-game testing to establish what *exactly* weapons do.

Additional features are poorly implemented.  The store system is unnecessary, providing no true limit on player builds past the very early game.  Engine load and weight already provide the necessary tools for balance.  Since you can buy and sell for the same price, in practice you simply buy, sell, buy, sell, buy, sell...it interrupts the flow of building, making the act of customizing your mecha a gigantic chore.

The story, as far as I have gotten, is poorly written and full of dull, unlikable characters with far too much dialogue for what they actually have to say.

Important missions are designed to be played halfway, failed, and restarted once the player has had a chance to tune their gear.  This is due to how the bossfights work, which are dependant on you having certain equipment to make them go by quickly enough to not drag on forever.  It's clear the devs are desperate for you to take a blade with you, but they only give you one blade for an extended period of time and it's kind of miserable to use.  It takes up a hand slot despite being  a wrist-mounted device.  You don't get any money for a failed mission, so it's just a way to waste player time.  

The "voice in your ear" characters are annoying to listen to, and only rarely have something useful to say.  Most of the commentary they give is cliche, and not in a funny way.  Just in a dull, unimaginative, hacky way.  Remember in Halo 2, how annoying it was to hear Cortana repeat the same voice line four or five times while trying to beat the game on higher difficulties?  It's that, but the character speaking never has any good lines to make up for it.  At least Cortana's lines in these situations tended to be more than "Don't let him bait you.  Focus."  

(Side Rant: He's not baiting ME you dumb fuck, he's baiting YOU.  I don't know who he is, I don't know who he's talking about, I don't give a single flying fuck about any of it.  Shut the hell up and let me do my job.  Like, at least do something useful and jam his comms so I don't have to hear his smug-ass dialogue)

Unfortunately, major mech games are rare and so it's still likely worth playing this game if you like mechs and can roll with the punches.  DO NOT pay full price for this title.  Fromsoft needs to be held to a standard appropriate for a professional, well-funded AAA studio.  If they put out a 30 dollar game that they take a loss on if they sell it for less than 50, that's not your problem.  That's their problem, and they can go bankrupt over it.


Edit:

I decided to see how far I could get,  I believe I got to the final boss of the first playthrough when I ran out of patience.  I just don't understand what people get out of this.  

If you decide to go ahead, understand that the game is *primarily* about what you have equipped.  Some weapons are simply much better than others.  Some weapons can excel in certain situations but are traps 90% of the time.  Some weapons do seem to just be bad.

I wish I could say I enjoyed my time, but the reality is that of the 40 hours I've spent with this game, I've enjoyed very little.

I am rather underwhelmed coming from 4 Answer to this. It looks nicer due to modern graphics, the story is nice, but campaign could be a lot longer, theres a distinct lack of giant bosses to fights (most bosses are player sized) and a lack of 'companies' to take jobs for. I could do without the stun mechanic and a more generous variation of unique weapons and mech parts. Not worth full price

Man, I really want to like this one. The core idea is so good, but the game just isn't good. It starts great with some cool boss fights, but then the game runs out of ideas and each boss fight is less interesting than the previous one. It's a bit of a classic FromSoft problem, where the game is front-loaded and the latter parts of the game feel cobbled together to get the game out the door. 

The story is just awful. It's not even a fun kind of bad, it's just not good, worse, it's boring.

It's just a shame. I really want to like this game. I just don't have the energy to finish it though. It's not good enough and the competition if fierce.

tried it twice // both times it felt like i was fighting two things at once the movement of the mech and the actual boss or target infront of me // tried it on keyboard and mouse and using a controller // neither helped, maybe the game isnt for me, but the movement was just not something i could get used to

I played AC2 back on the PS2 and was thinking about it recently. I decided to pick up AC6 more than 2 years after it came out. Beat the game and got all the endings. put over 100 hours into it, very fun single player experience. Went and tried my hand in PVP and quickly found that the net code is pretty terrible. reacting to projectiles is meaningless because they end up hitting you anyway. I travel for work, so i was playing on a slightly unstable connection, and I had a few DC's. couple that with the net code and you get a very unfun experience. After the 7th match in a row against the same person, who was using a weapon that was literally impossible to dodge under the circumstances, I Alt F4'd out of the game and went to lay down. went back the next day and I spent 20 minutes in the matchmaking queue with no games found. Come to find out, Fromsoftware had instituted a separate queue for people who frequently leave matches...I havent been able to get a game since. how long does it last? well also come to find out that it can last for months...great way to kill all the interest i had left in the game, and honestly pretty annoying. if someone DC's or quits a match...give them a loss. thats it. why make your own game unplayable?
